ai-mn136:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-mn136:2.1_0: Now at that time Venerable Samiddhi was staying in a wilderness hut.
ai-mn136:2.2_0: Then as the wanderer Potaliputta was going for a walk he came up to Venerable Samiddhi and went to him.
ai-mn136:2.2_1: and after going, he exchanged greetings with venerable Samiddhi.
ai-mn136:2.3_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-mn136:2.4_0: “Reverend Samiddhi, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the ascetic Gotama:
ai-mn136:2.5_0: ‘Deeds by way of body and speech are done in vain. Only mental deeds are real.’
ai-mn136:2.6_0: And: ‘There is such an attainment where the one who enters it does not feel anything at all.’”
ai-mn136:2.7_2: They should correct him, “No, don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for it’s not good to misrepresent the Buddha.
ai-mn136:2.7_3: for it’s not good to misrepresent him.
ai-mn136:2.7_4: The Buddha would never say such a thing.
ai-mn136:2.8_0: ‘Deeds by way of body and speech are done in vain. Only mental deeds are real.’
ai-mn136:2.9_0: But, reverend, there is such an attainment where the one who enters it does not feel anything at all.”
ai-mn136:2.10_0: “Reverend Samiddhi, how long has it been since you went forth?”
ai-mn136:2.12_0: “Well now, what could we say to the senior mendicants, what is the caravan leader to such a mendicant?
ai-mn136:2.13_0: After doing an intentional deed by way of body, speech, or mind, reverend, what does one feel?”
ai-mn136:2.14_0: “After doing an intentional deed to be experienced as painful by way of body, speech, or mind.”
ai-mn136:2.15_0: Then Potaliputta neither approved nor dismissed that mendicant’s statement.
ai-mn136:2.16_0: got up from his seat and left.
ai-mn136:3.1_0: Then, not long after Potaliputta had left, Venerable Ānanda went to see Venerable Ānanda
ai-mn136:3.1_1: and after approaching he exchanged greetings with venerable Ānanda,
ai-mn136:3.2_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-mn136:3.3_0: and informed Ānanda of all they had discussed.
ai-mn136:3.4_0: When he had spoken, Ānanda said to him,
ai-mn136:3.5_0: “Reverend Samiddhi, this is the discussion of the Buddha.
ai-mn136:3.6_0: Come, let’s go to the Buddha and inform him about this.
ai-mn136:3.7_0: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”
ai-mn136:4.1_0: Then venerable Ānanda and Samiddhi went to the Fortunate One,
ai-mn136:4.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-mn136:4.2_0: and told him what had happened.
ai-mn136:5.1_0: When he had spoken, the Buddha said to him,
ai-mn136:5.2_0: “I don’t recall even seeing the wanderer Potaliputta, Ānanda, so how could we have had such a discussion?
ai-mn136:5.3_0: And, Ānanda, when this Moggaliputta has answered definitively as wanderer Potaliputta.”
ai-mn136:6.1_0: When he had spoken, Venerable Udāyī said to the Buddha,
ai-mn136:6.2_0: “But sir, if that’s what Venerable Samiddhi said,
ai-mn136:6.4_0: Then the Buddha said to him,
ai-mn136:6.5_0: “See how this foolish person Udāyī comes up with an idea?
ai-mn136:6.7_0: he was going to come up with such an irrational idea.
ai-mn136:6.8_0: Whatever Suppiya was asked Ānanda about the three feelings.
ai-mn136:6.9_0: If he were to answer, Samiddhi would answer:
ai-mn136:6.10_0: ‘After doing an intentional deed to be experienced as pleasant by way of body, speech, or mind, one feels pleasure.
ai-mn136:6.11_0: After doing an intentional deed to be experienced as painful by way of body, speech, or mind, one feels pain.
ai-mn136:6.12_0: After doing an intentional deed to be experienced as neutral by way of body, speech, or mind, one feels neutral.’
ai-mn136:6.13_0: Answering in this way, Samiddhi would have rightly answered Potaliputta.
ai-mn136:6.14_0: Still, who are those foolish and incompetent wanderers who follow other paths to understand the Realized One’s great analysis of deeds?
ai-mn136:6.15_0: Ānanda, if only you would all listen to the Realized One’s explanation of the great analysis of deeds.”
ai-mn136:7.1_0: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One.
ai-mn136:7.2_0: Let the Buddha explain the great analysis of deeds. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
ai-mn136:7.3_0: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-mn136:8.1_0: “Ānanda, these four people are found in the world.
ai-mn136:8.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by four?
ai-mn136:8.3_0: Some person here kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, and have wrong view.
ai-mn136:8.4_0: But when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
ai-mn136:8.5_0: But some other person here kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, with wrong view.
ai-mn136:8.6_0: But when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
ai-mn136:8.7_0: But some other person here refrains from killing living creatures, stealing, committing sexual misconduct, or using speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, and have right view.

ai-mn136:17.1_0: Now, Ānanda, take the case of the person here who killed living creatures ...
ai-mn136:17.1_1: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
ai-mn136:17.2_0: They must have done a bad deed to be experienced as painful either previously or later, or else at the time of death they undertook wrong view.
ai-mn136:17.3_0: And that’s why, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
ai-mn136:17.4_0: But when they kill living creatures ...
ai-mn136:17.4_1: And they experience wrong view in the present life, or in the next life, or in some subsequent period.
ai-mn136:18.1_0: Now, Ānanda, take the case of the person here who killed living creatures ...

ai-mn136:18.2_0: They must have done a good deed to be experienced as pleasant either previously or later, or else at the time of death they undertook right view.

ai-mn136:21.1_0: So, Ānanda, there are deeds that are ineffective and appear ineffective. There are deeds that are ineffective but appear effective. There are deeds that are effective and appear effective. And there are deeds that are effective and appear effective.”
ai-mn136:21.2_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn136:21.3_0: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.
